issue.title: Handle crash properly
issue.body:
Workbench has some workarounds to avoid crashing when constructing invalid GtkBuilder.

Unfortunately that's probably never going to be enough if we don't want to crash at all. 

We shoul either:

1. Find a way to prevent all GtkBuilder related crashes - maybe by parsing the XML first in a separate process
2. Detect crash and start in "safe mode"

See https://github.com/sonnyp/Workbench/issues?q=crash

issue.title: Add VIM emulation
issue.body:
I've just recently started learning GTK and Workbench has been great for experimenting with UIs but my workflow is being hampered due to the lack of vim support.

Other GTK4 applications such as Builder, Text Editor already have vim support, so it'd be great if Workbench could have support for it as well.

If I'm not wrong, I think GtkSourceView already has [Vim emulation](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtksourceview/-/issues/233) support, so I'd at least hope that it'd not be too complicated to add support for vim. I don't know much about GTK yet, so that's all the info I can provide regarding possible implementations.
Thanks!

comment.body:
https://gnome.pages.gitlab.gnome.org/gtksourceview/gtksourceview5/class.VimIMContext.html it looks reasonably easy/straightforward to do and a good learning opportunity

Regarding 

> It is recommended that applications display the contents of ...

Let's start by showing it in the console – with `print` for example, and then we can discuss UI.

The example needs to be translated to JavaScript but that should be pretty easy https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gjs/-/blob/master/doc/Mapping.md

If anyone is interested in giving this a try: you can join us on the Matrix channel https://app.element.io/#/room/#workbench:matrix.org

issue.body:
### Steps to reproduce:

1. Open `Code` (JavaScript), UI (Blueprint) and Preview panel
2. Open the Welcome demo
3. Open the Icon Browser demo

### Expected result:

The demo loads normally and is interactive

### Actual result:

There is an exception in the console because the UI didn't update before the JS code is ran.
Due to Blueprint async complation step.

issue.title: Install (ARM) error at submodule update
issue.body:
Hi ; I'm trying to install Workbench ; I installed gnome-builder with apt in Ubuntu 22 Raspberry Pi edition.

Builder downloaded around a Gb during the "Installing necessary Sdk..." without errors, but after that I entered the Workbench repo directory and tried to install the dependencies as per the docs and got this error:
```
# git submodule update
Cloning into '/home/px/src/Workbench/troll'...
Submodule path 'blueprint-compiler': checked out '592ed7acab26f1633c03b0cd703a9cf2b7f09cb9'
fatal: Needed a single revision
fatal: Unable to find current revision in submodule path 'icon-development-kit-www'
```
Is Workench compatible with ARM? If it is, I may be missing some libraries..?

issue.title: Use Ctrl+W for closing application
issue.body:
After a while of using Tangram, I started to notice the shortcut for closing the application is **Ctrl+Q**. This is different from most applications having **Ctrl+W** as shortcut for closing. It is especially annoying if you are used to the keyboard-only workflow.

With this issue, I suggest changing the behavior for this shortcut to adapt to almost all other applications. I would be happy to create a PR for this.

Regards
Tristan

issue.title: Cannot build from source (Help wanted / no bug)
issue.body:
**Tangram version**

Source from main branch (00867d915df6348a90e0b8288e3f4cd1b9b6d344)

**Linux distribution**

Fedora 36

**Flatpak version**

Flatpak 1.12.7

**Desktop environment**

GNOME 42.4


I want to build Tangram from source. Problem is, I'm just starting out with Meson, GTK, etc. That's probably why I wasn't able to build it so far. I tried different paths, so far:

- Using GNOME Builder and just pressing "build"
- Trying to build manually with meson
- Using run.sh

As far as I can tell from the README and #128 and #169, I should be able to clone the repository, initialize the troll git submodule, and then click on "build" in GNOME builder. I get the following error:

```
flatpak build --env=LANG=en_GB.UTF-8 --env=USER=chiff --env=HOME=/home/chiff --env=PATH=/usr/bin:/bin --env=TERM=xterm-256color --env=V=0 --env=CCACHE_DIR=/home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder/flatpak-builder/ccache --env=FLATPAK_CONFIG_DIR=/home/chiff/.local/share/gnome-builder/flatpak/etc --env=PATH=/app/bin:/usr/bin --env=G_MESSAGES_DEBUG= --env=XDG_RUNTIME_DIR=/run/user/1000 --build-dir=/home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder/projects/Tangram/builds/re.sonny.Tangram.json-flatpak-org.gnome.Platform-master-x86_64-main --share=network --nofilesystem=host --filesystem=/home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder --filesystem=/home/chiff/Projects/Tangram --filesystem=/home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder/projects/Tangram/builds/re.sonny.Tangram.json-flatpak-org.gnome.Platform-master-x86_64-main --env=NOCONFIGURE=1 /home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder/projects/Tangram/flatpak/staging/x86_64-main ninja
[0/1] Regenerating build files.

ERROR: Neither directory contains a build file meson.build.
FAILED: build.ninja 
/usr/bin/meson --internal regenerate /home/chiff/dev/project/Tangram /home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder/projects/Tangram/builds/re.sonny.Tangram.json-flatpak-org.gnome.Platform-master-x86_64-main --backend ninja
ninja: error: rebuilding 'build.ninja': subcommand failed
```

I also tried running `run.sh` but there I get the following error:

```
[chiff@fedora Tangram]$ ./run.sh
Failed to open file “data/re.sonny.Tangram.data.gresource.xml”: No such file or directory

(re.sonny.Tangram:799929): Gjs-WARNING **: 11:49:50.251: JS ERROR: Error: Requiring WebKit2, version 5.0: Typelib file for namespace 'WebKit2', version '5.0' not found
require@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/esm/gi.js:14:24
@gi://WebKit2?version=5.0:3:25
@file:///home/chiff/Projects/Tangram/re.sonny.Tangram:67:6

```

I have installed the following packages, related to webkit:

```
[chiff@fedora Tangram]$ dnf list --installed | grep webkit
libproxy-webkitgtk4.x86_64                        0.4.18-1.fc36                       @updates                                         
qt5-qtwebkit.x86_64                               5.212.0-0.68.alpha4.fc36            @updates                                         
webkit2gtk3.x86_64                                2.38.0-2.fc36                       @updates                                         
webkit2gtk3-jsc.x86_64                            2.38.0-2.fc36                       @updates
```

I'm pretty sure, that it's quite simple to fix, but my knowledge of the GNOME development ecosystem is lacking.

If someone could give me some pointers, and the correct, recommended way to build Tangram from source, that would be much appreciated.

comment.body: Fixed in `main` - please try again with GNOME Builder and confirm.

issue.title: Does gjspack plan on supporting custom file handlers?

comment.body:
So I'd like to experiment more with JSX in GJS. I still want to keep stack traces. The only transformer I know of which can do this is babel with the [retainLines](https://babeljs.io/docs/en/options#retainlines) option.

Having custom file handlers would help with that.

> Such a simple interface also doesn't work well for Blueprint because the CLI compiler is too slow for the DX I'm aiming for. I'm currently experimenting with using compile-batch or LSP.

This is not true anymore since https://gitlab.gnome.org/jwestman/blueprint-compiler/-/commit/06f54c8ff8d5f7c78c1d21bcbc59fdd87ce14910

So Blueprint could become a generic file handler as well.

I've noticed a small issue: when running Junction as a Flatpak with it set as the default web browser, it's unable to open hyperlinks in its own About dialog. Running `flatpak run re.sonny.Junction` and then clicking on a link in the About dialog yields the following output:

```

(re.sonny.Junction:3): Gtk-WARNING **: <timestamp>: Couldn't unexport handle for GdkX11Toplevel surface, unsupported windowing system

pull_request.title: Show transfered file in folder as default action of notification (replaces #1039)
pull_request.body:
This PR finishes up the changes for PR #1039, with most of the work done by @HaMF over there. I just tacked on a commit with some review suggestions. Differences from the original PR:

1. The function is renamed `showPathInFolder`, as suggested
2. In addition to being the default click action for the notification, it's also made the "Open Folder" button action. (Now renamed to "Show File Location". I decided that "Open File Location" and "Open File" right next to each other was too confusing, so I didn't go with that.)
3. The D-Bus call made to launch the file manager now passes a result callback that finishes the request, or logs an error if encountered.

Closes #1009 
<s>Closes #1039  (←- I don't think this will work, but...)</s> It does not work, probably-sensibly.

issue.title: Slow startup time for some users
issue.body:
If I don't have the Junction app open already, there is a waiting period of about 2-4 seconds between clicking a link or file and the Junction popup appearing.
Probably inevitable because it's a flatpak, current solution is to run the App and hide the window. Maybe add a background process that starts on boot?

Original title: Add background process / system tray icon

issue.title: Junction can't open its own website from the About dialog when running as a Flatpak
issue.body:
Hi there, thanks for this application, it's extremely useful!

I've noticed a small issue: when running Junction as a Flatpak with it set as the default web browser, it's unable to open hyperlinks in its own About dialog. Running `flatpak run re.sonny.Junction` and then clicking on a link in the About dialog yields the following output:

```
sh: line 1: exec: flatpak: not found

(re.sonny.Junction:3): Gtk-WARNING **: <timestamp>: Couldn't unexport handle for GdkX11Toplevel surface, unsupported windowing system
```

comment.body:
Actually, I can't reproduce with Junction 1.5.0 (available on Flathub) on Fedora 37.

```
flatpak run re.sonny.Junction//stable
```

Can you share more details about your env? In Junction about window there is a `System` section.

issue.title: Fails to start under wayland on wsl2
issue.body:
Hi, I installed it on wsl2, which uses Wayland under the hood (Using normal `flatpak install flathub re.sonny.Workbench`).

It seems like when starting, it crashes with this error:

```
Gdk-xdg_wm_base@22: error 4: xdg_surface buffer (800 x 600) does not match the configured maximized state (0 x 0)


Gdk-Message: 23:30:37.687: Error 71 (Protocol error) dispatching to Wayland display.
```

Other gtk4 Flatpak bundled applications seem to work fine. I am wondering if there is anything I could try to make this work nonetheless.

issue.title: LibreWolf browser has broken icon
issue.body:
I use the LibreWolf browser as my main browser and its icon is broken in Junction. The application works fine, the icon is just missing. I have LibreWolf installed as a regular application. LibreWolf is a fork of Firefox so I assume it installs similarly to regular Firefox.

The path for the desktop icon is `/usr/share/applications/librewolf.desktop`
The contents of the desktop file is:
```
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Name=LibreWolf
GenericName=Web Browser
# Gnome and KDE 3 uses Comment.
Comment=Web Browser
StartupNotify=true
Terminal=false
Type=Application
MimeType=application/json;application/pdf;application/rdf+xml;application/rss+xml;application/xhtml+xml;application/xhtml_xml;application/xml;image/gif;image/jpeg;image/png;image/webp;text/html;text/xml;x-scheme-handler/http;x-scheme-handler/https;
Comment=LibreWolf Browser
Categories=Network;WebBrowser;Security;
StartupWMClass=librewolf-default
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf %u
Icon=/usr/share/librewolf/browser/chrome/icons/default/default64.png

Actions=new-window;new-private-window;safe-mode;preferences;

[Desktop Action new-window]
Name=New Window
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf
[Desktop Action new-private-window]
Name=New Private Window
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf --private-window %u
[Desktop Action safe-mode]
Name=Start in Safe Mode
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf --safe-mode
[Desktop Action preferences]
Name=Show Preferences
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf --preferences
```

I have Brave Browser installed via Flatpak and that works correctly. 

I have attached a video showing the broken icon:
[JunctionLibreWolf.webm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68185249/194785279-51ccff0f-a90a-4ea4-b4be-a954e48831d3.webm)

comment.body:
Can you confirm it's fixed in this beta version?

```
flatpak install --user https://dl.flathub.org/build-repo/114055/re.sonny.Junction.flatpakref
flatpak run re.sonny.Junction//test https://example.com
```

issue.title: Browser doesn't open
issue.body:
Trying to open an URL with Firefox or ungoogled Chromium _sometimes_ doesn't succeed. When invoking Junction via commandline an error is displayed:
`Error: no DISPLAY environment variable specified`
Also trying to set the variable via `flatpak run env="DISPLAY=:0" re.sonny.Junction <URL>` doesn't work.
Nevertheless opening with GNOME Web (Epiphany) always works.

I'm on Fedora Silverblue with system-provided Firefox. Junction, Epiphany and ungoogled Chromium are installed via Flathub.

issue.title: Handle crash properly
issue.body:
Workbench has some workarounds to avoid crashing when constructing invalid GtkBuilder.

Unfortunately that's probably never going to be enough if we don't want to crash at all. 

We shoul either:

1. Find a way to prevent all GtkBuilder related crashes - maybe by parsing the XML first in a separate process
2. Detect crash and start in "safe mode"

See https://github.com/sonnyp/Workbench/issues?q=crash

issue.title: Add VIM emulation
issue.body:
I've just recently started learning GTK and Workbench has been great for experimenting with UIs but my workflow is being hampered due to the lack of vim support.

Other GTK4 applications such as Builder, Text Editor already have vim support, so it'd be great if Workbench could have support for it as well.

If I'm not wrong, I think GtkSourceView already has [Vim emulation](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtksourceview/-/issues/233) support, so I'd at least hope that it'd not be too complicated to add support for vim. I don't know much about GTK yet, so that's all the info I can provide regarding possible implementations.
Thanks!

comment.body:
https://gnome.pages.gitlab.gnome.org/gtksourceview/gtksourceview5/class.VimIMContext.html it looks reasonably easy/straightforward to do and a good learning opportunity

Regarding 

> It is recommended that applications display the contents of ...

Let's start by showing it in the console – with `print` for example, and then we can discuss UI.

The example needs to be translated to JavaScript but that should be pretty easy https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gjs/-/blob/master/doc/Mapping.md

If anyone is interested in giving this a try: you can join us on the Matrix channel https://app.element.io/#/room/#workbench:matrix.org

issue.title: Demo fails to load when Blueprint is selected
issue.body:
### Steps to reproduce:

1. Open `Code` (JavaScript), UI (Blueprint) and Preview panel
2. Open the Welcome demo
3. Open the Icon Browser demo

### Expected result:

The demo loads normally and is interactive

### Actual result:

There is an exception in the console because the UI didn't update before the JS code is ran.
Due to Blueprint async complation step.

commits.message:
Fix Run and demo loading when using Blueprint

Fixes https://github.com/sonnyp/Workbench/issues/157

issue.title: Install (ARM) error at submodule update
issue.body:
Hi ; I'm trying to install Workbench ; I installed gnome-builder with apt in Ubuntu 22 Raspberry Pi edition.

Builder downloaded around a Gb during the "Installing necessary Sdk..." without errors, but after that I entered the Workbench repo directory and tried to install the dependencies as per the docs and got this error:
```
# git submodule update
Cloning into '/home/px/src/Workbench/troll'...
Submodule path 'blueprint-compiler': checked out '592ed7acab26f1633c03b0cd703a9cf2b7f09cb9'
fatal: Needed a single revision
fatal: Unable to find current revision in submodule path 'icon-development-kit-www'
```
Is Workench compatible with ARM? If it is, I may be missing some libraries..?

issue.title: Use Ctrl+W for closing application
issue.body:
After a while of using Tangram, I started to notice the shortcut for closing the application is **Ctrl+Q**. This is different from most applications having **Ctrl+W** as shortcut for closing. It is especially annoying if you are used to the keyboard-only workflow.

With this issue, I suggest changing the behavior for this shortcut to adapt to almost all other applications. I would be happy to create a PR for this.

Regards
Tristan

issue.title: Cannot build from source (Help wanted / no bug)
issue.body:
**Tangram version**

Source from main branch (00867d915df6348a90e0b8288e3f4cd1b9b6d344)

**Linux distribution**

Fedora 36

**Flatpak version**

Flatpak 1.12.7

**Desktop environment**

GNOME 42.4


I want to build Tangram from source. Problem is, I'm just starting out with Meson, GTK, etc. That's probably why I wasn't able to build it so far. I tried different paths, so far:

- Using GNOME Builder and just pressing "build"
- Trying to build manually with meson
- Using run.sh

issue.title: Does gjspack plan on supporting custom file handlers?

comment.body:
So I'd like to experiment more with JSX in GJS. I still want to keep stack traces. The only transformer I know of which can do this is babel with the [retainLines](https://babeljs.io/docs/en/options#retainlines) option.

Having custom file handlers would help with that.

> Such a simple interface also doesn't work well for Blueprint because the CLI compiler is too slow for the DX I'm aiming for. I'm currently experimenting with using compile-batch or LSP.

This is not true anymore since https://gitlab.gnome.org/jwestman/blueprint-compiler/-/commit/06f54c8ff8d5f7c78c1d21bcbc59fdd87ce14910

So Blueprint could become a generic file handler as well.

pull_request.title: Show transfered file in folder as default action of notification (replaces #1039)
pull_request.body:
This PR finishes up the changes for PR #1039, with most of the work done by @HaMF over there. I just tacked on a commit with some review suggestions. Differences from the original PR:

1. The function is renamed `showPathInFolder`, as suggested
2. In addition to being the default click action for the notification, it's also made the "Open Folder" button action. (Now renamed to "Show File Location". I decided that "Open File Location" and "Open File" right next to each other was too confusing, so I didn't go with that.)
3. The D-Bus call made to launch the file manager now passes a result callback that finishes the request, or logs an error if encountered.

Closes #1009 
<s>Closes #1039  (←- I don't think this will work, but...)</s> It does not work, probably-sensibly.

I use the LibreWolf browser as my main browser and its icon is broken in Junction. The application works fine, the icon is just missing. I have LibreWolf installed as a regular application. LibreWolf is a fork of Firefox so I assume it installs similarly to regular Firefox.

The path for the desktop icon is `/usr/share/applications/librewolf.desktop`
The contents of the desktop file is:
```
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Name=LibreWolf
GenericName=Web Browser
# Gnome and KDE 3 uses Comment.
Comment=Web Browser
StartupNotify=true
Terminal=false
Type=Application
MimeType=application/json;application/pdf;application/rdf+xml;application/rss+xml;application/xhtml+xml;application/xhtml_xml;application/xml;image/gif;image/jpeg;image/png;image/webp;text/html;text/xml;x-scheme-handler/http;x-scheme-handler/https;
Comment=LibreWolf Browser
Categories=Network;WebBrowser;Security;
StartupWMClass=librewolf-default
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf %u

Actions=new-window;new-private-window;safe-mode;preferences;

[Desktop Action new-window]
Name=New Window
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf
[Desktop Action new-private-window]

issue.title: Handle crash properly
issue.body:
Workbench has some workarounds to avoid crashing when constructing invalid GtkBuilder.

Unfortunately that's probably never going to be enough if we don't want to crash at all. 

We shoul either:

1. Find a way to prevent all GtkBuilder related crashes - maybe by parsing the XML first in a separate process
2. Detect crash and start in "safe mode"

See https://github.com/sonnyp/Workbench/issues?q=crash

issue.title: Add VIM emulation
issue.body:
I've just recently started learning GTK and Workbench has been great for experimenting with UIs but my workflow is being hampered due to the lack of vim support.

Other GTK4 applications such as Builder, Text Editor already have vim support, so it'd be great if Workbench could have support for it as well.

If I'm not wrong, I think GtkSourceView already has [Vim emulation](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtksourceview/-/issues/233) support, so I'd at least hope that it'd not be too complicated to add support for vim. I don't know much about GTK yet, so that's all the info I can provide regarding possible implementations.
Thanks!

comment.body:
https://gnome.pages.gitlab.gnome.org/gtksourceview/gtksourceview5/class.VimIMContext.html it looks reasonably easy/straightforward to do and a good learning opportunity

Regarding 

> It is recommended that applications display the contents of ...

Let's start by showing it in the console – with `print` for example, and then we can discuss UI.

The example needs to be translated to JavaScript but that should be pretty easy https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gjs/-/blob/master/doc/Mapping.md

If anyone is interested in giving this a try: you can join us on the Matrix channel https://app.element.io/#/room/#workbench:matrix.org

issue.title: Use Ctrl+W for closing application
issue.body:
After a while of using Tangram, I started to notice the shortcut for closing the application is **Ctrl+Q**. This is different from most applications having **Ctrl+W** as shortcut for closing. It is especially annoying if you are used to the keyboard-only workflow.

With this issue, I suggest changing the behavior for this shortcut to adapt to almost all other applications. I would be happy to create a PR for this.

Regards
Tristan

issue.title: Cannot build from source (Help wanted / no bug)
issue.body:

Source from main branch (00867d915df6348a90e0b8288e3f4cd1b9b6d344)

**Linux distribution**

Fedora 36

**Flatpak version**

Flatpak 1.12.7

GNOME 42.4

```
flatpak build --env=LANG=en_GB.UTF-8 --env=USER=chiff --env=HOME=/home/chiff --env=PATH=/usr/bin:/bin --env=TERM=xterm-256color --env=V=0 --env=CCACHE_DIR=/home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder/flatpak-builder/ccache --env=FLATPAK_CONFIG_DIR=/home/chiff/.local/share/gnome-builder/flatpak/etc --env=PATH=/app/bin:/usr/bin --env=G_MESSAGES_DEBUG= --env=XDG_RUNTIME_DIR=/run/user/1000 --build-dir=/home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder/projects/Tangram/builds/re.sonny.Tangram.json-flatpak-org.gnome.Platform-master-x86_64-main --share=network --nofilesystem=host --filesystem=/home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder --filesystem=/home/chiff/Projects/Tangram --filesystem=/home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder/projects/Tangram/builds/re.sonny.Tangram.json-flatpak-org.gnome.Platform-master-x86_64-main --env=NOCONFIGURE=1 /home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder/projects/Tangram/flatpak/staging/x86_64-main ninja
[0/1] Regenerating build files.

ERROR: Neither directory contains a build file meson.build.
FAILED: build.ninja 
/usr/bin/meson --internal regenerate /home/chiff/dev/project/Tangram /home/chiff/.cache/gnome-builder/projects/Tangram/builds/re.sonny.Tangram.json-flatpak-org.gnome.Platform-master-x86_64-main --backend ninja
ninja: error: rebuilding 'build.ninja': subcommand failed
```

I also tried running `run.sh` but there I get the following error:

```
[chiff@fedora Tangram]$ ./run.sh
Failed to open file “data/re.sonny.Tangram.data.gresource.xml”: No such file or directory

(re.sonny.Tangram:799929): Gjs-WARNING **: 11:49:50.251: JS ERROR: Error: Requiring WebKit2, version 5.0: Typelib file for namespace 'WebKit2', version '5.0' not found

@gi://WebKit2?version=5.0:3:25
@file:///home/chiff/Projects/Tangram/re.sonny.Tangram:67:6

[chiff@fedora Tangram]$ dnf list --installed | grep webkit
libproxy-webkitgtk4.x86_64                        0.4.18-1.fc36                       @updates                                         
qt5-qtwebkit.x86_64                               5.212.0-0.68.alpha4.fc36            @updates                                         
webkit2gtk3.x86_64                                2.38.0-2.fc36                       @updates                                         
webkit2gtk3-jsc.x86_64                            2.38.0-2.fc36                       @updates

I'm pretty sure, that it's quite simple to fix, but my knowledge of the GNOME development ecosystem is lacking.

If someone could give me some pointers, and the correct, recommended way to build Tangram from source, that would be much appreciated.

issue.title: Does gjspack plan on supporting custom file handlers?

comment.body:
So I'd like to experiment more with JSX in GJS. I still want to keep stack traces. The only transformer I know of which can do this is babel with the [retainLines](https://babeljs.io/docs/en/options#retainlines) option.

Having custom file handlers would help with that.

> Such a simple interface also doesn't work well for Blueprint because the CLI compiler is too slow for the DX I'm aiming for. I'm currently experimenting with using compile-batch or LSP.

This is not true anymore since https://gitlab.gnome.org/jwestman/blueprint-compiler/-/commit/06f54c8ff8d5f7c78c1d21bcbc59fdd87ce14910

So Blueprint could become a generic file handler as well.

issue.title: Junction can't open its own website from the About dialog when running as a Flatpak
issue.body:
Hi there, thanks for this application, it's extremely useful!

I've noticed a small issue: when running Junction as a Flatpak with it set as the default web browser, it's unable to open hyperlinks in its own About dialog. Running `flatpak run re.sonny.Junction` and then clicking on a link in the About dialog yields the following output:

```
sh: line 1: exec: flatpak: not found

(re.sonny.Junction:3): Gtk-WARNING **: <timestamp>: Couldn't unexport handle for GdkX11Toplevel surface, unsupported windowing system
```

pull_request.title: Show transfered file in folder as default action of notification (replaces #1039)
pull_request.body:
This PR finishes up the changes for PR #1039, with most of the work done by @HaMF over there. I just tacked on a commit with some review suggestions. Differences from the original PR:

1. The function is renamed `showPathInFolder`, as suggested
2. In addition to being the default click action for the notification, it's also made the "Open Folder" button action. (Now renamed to "Show File Location". I decided that "Open File Location" and "Open File" right next to each other was too confusing, so I didn't go with that.)
3. The D-Bus call made to launch the file manager now passes a result callback that finishes the request, or logs an error if encountered.

Closes #1009 
<s>Closes #1039  (←- I don't think this will work, but...)</s> It does not work, probably-sensibly.

Probably inevitable because it's a flatpak, current solution is to run the App and hide the window. Maybe add a background process that starts on boot?

issue.title: Fails to start under wayland on wsl2
issue.body:
Hi, I installed it on wsl2, which uses Wayland under the hood (Using normal `flatpak install flathub re.sonny.Workbench`).

It seems like when starting, it crashes with this error:

```
Gdk-xdg_wm_base@22: error 4: xdg_surface buffer (800 x 600) does not match the configured maximized state (0 x 0)


Gdk-Message: 23:30:37.687: Error 71 (Protocol error) dispatching to Wayland display.
```

Other gtk4 Flatpak bundled applications seem to work fine. I am wondering if there is anything I could try to make this work nonetheless.

issue.title: LibreWolf browser has broken icon
issue.body:
I use the LibreWolf browser as my main browser and its icon is broken in Junction. The application works fine, the icon is just missing. I have LibreWolf installed as a regular application. LibreWolf is a fork of Firefox so I assume it installs similarly to regular Firefox.

The path for the desktop icon is `/usr/share/applications/librewolf.desktop`
The contents of the desktop file is:
```
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Name=LibreWolf
GenericName=Web Browser
# Gnome and KDE 3 uses Comment.
Comment=Web Browser
StartupNotify=true
Terminal=false
Type=Application
MimeType=application/json;application/pdf;application/rdf+xml;application/rss+xml;application/xhtml+xml;application/xhtml_xml;application/xml;image/gif;image/jpeg;image/png;image/webp;text/html;text/xml;x-scheme-handler/http;x-scheme-handler/https;
Comment=LibreWolf Browser
Categories=Network;WebBrowser;Security;
StartupWMClass=librewolf-default
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf %u
Icon=/usr/share/librewolf/browser/chrome/icons/default/default64.png

Actions=new-window;new-private-window;safe-mode;preferences;

[Desktop Action new-window]
Name=New Window
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf
[Desktop Action new-private-window]
Name=New Private Window
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf --private-window %u
[Desktop Action safe-mode]
Name=Start in Safe Mode
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf --safe-mode
[Desktop Action preferences]
Name=Show Preferences
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf --preferences
```

I have Brave Browser installed via Flatpak and that works correctly. 

I have attached a video showing the broken icon:
[JunctionLibreWolf.webm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68185249/194785279-51ccff0f-a90a-4ea4-b4be-a954e48831d3.webm)

comment.body:
Can you confirm it's fixed in this beta version?

```
flatpak install --user https://dl.flathub.org/build-repo/114055/re.sonny.Junction.flatpakref
flatpak run re.sonny.Junction//test https://example.com
```

issue.title: Browser doesn't open
issue.body:
Trying to open an URL with Firefox or ungoogled Chromium _sometimes_ doesn't succeed. When invoking Junction via commandline an error is displayed:
`Error: no DISPLAY environment variable specified`
Also trying to set the variable via `flatpak run env="DISPLAY=:0" re.sonny.Junction <URL>` doesn't work.
Nevertheless opening with GNOME Web (Epiphany) always works.

I'm on Fedora Silverblue with system-provided Firefox. Junction, Epiphany and ungoogled Chromium are installed via Flathub.

Actions=new-window;new-private-window;safe-mode;preferences;

[Desktop Action new-window]
Name=New Window
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf
[Desktop Action new-private-window]
Name=New Private Window
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf --private-window %u
[Desktop Action safe-mode]
Name=Start in Safe Mode
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf --safe-mode
[Desktop Action preferences]
Name=Show Preferences
Exec=/usr/share/librewolf/librewolf --preferences
```

I have Brave Browser installed via Flatpak and that works correctly.
